A serial of WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts (a = 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) was synthesized by sol-gel method, which exhibited high NH3-SCR denitrification performance in a wide activity temperature window. W0.08Co0.4TiOx achieve best SCR activity (over 90% NO conversion) at 190–430 °C and good resistance to H2O/SO2. Various characterizations were used to investigate the influence of W doping on physicochemical property of these catalysts. Especially, in-situ DRIFTS were used to evaluate the type of acid sites, NOx adsorption, the reactivity of surface adsorption species, and the influences of H2O/SO2 on adsorption of NOx and NH3. The doping of W enhanced the acidity and weakened the oxidation capacity of WaCo0.4TiOx, but higher surface acidity, especial more Brønsted acid sites, can compensate for the effect of the decrease in the oxidation capacity on low-temperature activity. The optimal activity over W0.08Co0.4TiOx can be derived from the synergistic effect of surface acidity and oxidation performance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords WCoTiOx oxides catalyst Selective catalytic reduction Ammonia NOx removal Effect of acidity 1 Introduction The problem of environmental pollution has attracted much attention in recent years. Nitrogen oxides (NOx), as the main gas pollution, can not only cause acid rain and photochemical smog, but also seriously affect the human health [1]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx by NH3 is an effective NOx removal method, and the catalyst is its core. V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 is the most widely used commercial catalyst for the NOx elimination of stationary source, but it still has many defects, such as a narrow temperature window (300–400 °C) and biological toxicity of V element and unselective oxidation of NH3 to produce N2O at high temperature [1–4]. In addition, emission temperature of exhaust gas is generally less than 300 °C from some industrial boilers, coal-fired heaters, combustion furnaces, glass melting furnaces and other stationary resources [5]. Therefore, vanadium-free denitrification (de-NOx) catalysts with high catalytic performance have been concerned. In recent years, people have been focusing on the development of high efficiency and environmentally friendly mixed metal oxides NH3-SCR catalysts instead of vanadium-based catalysts, for instance Fe [6,7], Mn [8,9], Ce [10,11], Cu [12,13] oxides-based catalysts. However, the above catalysts also have some shortcomings which limit their practical application. Among the transition metals, Co oxides show special role in the low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts because of its high oxygen mobility and good oxidation property [14,15]. Hu et al. researched that the strong interaction between Mn and Co promoted the NH3-SCR activity of the mesoporous 3D MnxCo3−xO4 nanosphere at low temperature [16]. Gao et al. found that the introduction of Co to the MnOx-CeO2 catalyst can be beneficial to the low-temperature activity and resistance to SO2 [17]. Gao et al. found that the composite oxides MnCo2O4 showed the excellent water resistance and low-temperature activity due to the large number of Brønsted acid sites on the surface [18]. Meng et al. proposed that the abundant surface Co3+ was beneficial to the low-temperature activity of the Co3O4 nanorods [19]. In our previous work [20,21], we found that Co doping was beneficial to NOx adsorption and can improve the surface chemisorbed oxygen content. The higher the Co3+ content, the better the low temperature activity, because NO can be oxidized to NO2 at low temperature, promoting the occurrence of “fast SCR” reaction. However, Co oxide as active component has strong oxidization effect on NH3, leading to poor N2 selectivity and NO conversion at high temperature. Therefore, it is a challenge how to tune the oxidation ability to obtain good low-temperature and high-temperature activity (wider activity temperature window) on Co-based catalysts by modifying other metals. In addition, tungsten as acid sites in the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst plays an important function in improving the SCR activity. Recently, some catalysts containing W were developed for SCR reaction, such as Fe-W oxides [22], Ce-W oxides [23], Mn-W oxides [24], Ti-W oxides [25] etc. Generally, in the NH3-SCR process, W doping can enhance catalytic activity and H2O/SO2 tolerance effectively. In general, WO3 has a poor oxidation capacity, and NH3 is not oxidized to N2O on its surface. In addition, doping/loading of W in catalysts can usually reduce the oxidation capacity of catalyst, which is not helpful in low-temperature NO conversion. We previously discovered [26] that a little quantity of W can maintain a moderate oxidation property of Cu0.02Fe0.2WaTiOx catalyst and significantly increase the acid sites (especially the B-acid sites) on the catalyst, leading to the enhanced activity and selectivity at high temperature due to the synergistic impact between acidity and redox capacity of the catalyst from addition of tungsten. In fact, we also found [27] that the introduction of W can cause the W0.18CeOx catalyst to generate a high number of B-acid sites, improving adsorption and activation of NH3 at low temperature and enhancing the reaction activity of adsorbed NH3 species with NOx. This means that the low-temperature activity can be increased by enhancing acidity to compensate for the loss of oxidation. Thus, we came up with the idea that doping W into Co-based catalyst obtained low temperature NH3-SCR denitrification catalysts by improving acidity and controlling oxidation ability to tune the synergistic effects between oxidation property and acidity. In this paper, a series of WaCo0.4TiOx mixed oxide catalysts with changing tungsten amount was prepared by sol-gel method. The relationship between NH3-SCR activity and physicochemical properties of the catalysts was systematically studied by XRD, Raman, XPS, In-situ DRIFTS etc. It was found that although a small amount of tungsten doping reduced the oxidation capacity of the catalysts, it could enhance the surface acidity of the catalyst, leading to better low-temperature activity and high-temperature selectivity. 2 Experimental The WaCo0.4TiOx (a = 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) mixed oxides catalysts were prepared by one-step sol-gel method, in which the molar ratio of W, Co and Ti is a:0.4:1. The Co0.4TiOx catalyst was also prepared as reference. Various characterization was used to analyze the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, N2 physical adsorption, Temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR), Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3/NO (NH3-TPD/NO-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscope (TEM), In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). Detailed experimental procedures of preparation, characterization and catalytic activity tests of the catalysts were presented in the Supplement materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity for NH3-SCR The NH3-SCR de-NOx performance was evaluated over the Co0.4TiOx and WaCo0.4TiOx (a= 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) catalysts in the range of 100–500 °C. The NO conversion of the Co0.4TiOx catalyst is high at low temperature, as shown in Fig. 1A, but it declines rapidly at 250 °C, and its active temperature window is quite limited (190–220 °C). For the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, the low temperature activity is almost unchanged and the high temperature activity is enhanced compared with the Co0.4TiOx catalyst, as a result, they show a wider temperature window. Moreover, the increase in tungsten concentration improves NO conversion at high temperature. In addition, the low temperature SCR activity over W0.10Co0.4TiOx is lower than that over other WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts. Among these catalysts, the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst displays the optimum SCR activity with > 90% NO conversion at 190–430 °C. Fig. 1B shows the N2 selectivity of all catalysts. Obviously, the N2 selectivity of catalysts Co0.4TiOx is much lower and decreases at 160 °C. However, as the content of tungsten increases in the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, N2 selectivity becomes better. W0.08Co0.4TiOx displays good selectivity to N2 in the whole reaction temperature window. It is interesting that the N2 selectivity of all catalysts decreases first below 300 °C and then increases above 300 °C, which may be caused by the decomposition of N2O to N2 at higher temperature. Based on good SCR performance of W0.08Co0.4TiOx, we further investigated the activity under different GHSV and activity stability with time. Fig. 1C shows that the NO conversion still exceeds 90% in the temperature range of 220–400 °C under GHSV of 80,000 h−1, while it is in range of 190–430 °C under GHSV of 40,000 h−1. Furthermore, about 90% NO conversion is unchanged in 55 h at 180 °C over the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst under 40,000 h−1 (Fig. 1D), demonstrating the high activity durability of the catalyst at low temperature. In the NH3-SCR reaction, SO2 and H2O are the primary deactivation species. As a result, it is crucial to investigate the effects of SO2 and H2O on NH3-SCR activity. As exhibited in Fig. 1E and F, the resistance to SO2 and H2O was tested on Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx. Obviously, Co0.4TiOx shows poor resistance to SO2 and H2O (Fig. 1E). For W0.08Co0.4TiOx, before the addition of SO2 and H2O in the feed, the reaction was operated for 1 h (Fig. 1F). After adding 3% H2O at 200 °C for 5 h, the NO conversion drops to 80% over W0.08Co0.4TiOx, but it returns to 100% when the H2O supply is removed. When the reaction temperature increases to 240 °C and 3% H2O is added, the NO conversion stabilizes at 90% within 1 h but still recovers after removing H2O over W0.08Co0.4TiOx. However, the NO conversion goes down to 60% over Co0.4TiOx at 200 °C after adding 3% H2O for 5 h (Fig. 1E), indicating that the addition of H2O has more negative effect on the activity on Co0.4TiOx than on W0.08Co0.4TiOx. These results reveal that the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst displays much better resistance to H2O than Co0.4TiOx, which is considered as important property for industrial application. Furthermore, in presence of 50 ppm SO2 in the feed without H2O, the NO conversion decreases from 80% to 50% at 240 °C over Co0.4TiOx (Fig. 1E), but it only reduces to 82% from 100% over W0.08Co0.4TiOx under the same condition (Fig. 1F). The observations suggest that the presence of SO2 can limit significantly the SCR reaction on Co0.4TiOx to a degree. As exhibited in Fig. S1, the results of resistance to SO2 and H2O at 280 °C also confirm that W0.08Co0.4TiOx has better catalytic performance than Co0.4TiOx in presence of H2O/SO2. In short, addition of W in W0.08Co0.4TiOx can improve the high-temperature activity of NH3-SCR as well as SO2 and H2O resistance. 3.2 Structure analysis 3.2.1 XRD results The XRD patterns ( Fig. 2A) of all the Co0.4TiOx and WaCo0.4TiOx (a=0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) catalysts show the peaks at 2θ = 25.29, 37.92, 47.86, 54.82 and 62.52 ° that are attributed to the (101), (004), (200), (211) and (204) crystallographic plane reflections of anatase TiO2 phase (PDF#21–1272), respectively [28]. Moreover, these diffraction peaks do not show any shift, and no signals of WOx and CoOx species are observed for the WaCo0.4TiOx (a=0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) catalysts, implying that WOx and CoOx species are amorphous or highly dispersed on the surface of the catalysts. Additionally, the crystallinity of the catalyst decreases with the increase of the tungsten content. The crystal particle size of all samples was calculated by using crystal plane (101) of TiO2 in XRD data based on the Scherrer formula. The crystal particle size of catalyst Co0.4TiOx is 13.1 nm, while that of W0.04Co0.4TiOx, W0.06Co0.4TiOx, W0.08Co0.4TiOx, W0.10Co0.4TiOx is 14.1, 13.0, 12.0 and 10.8 nm, respectively, increasing as the doping of tungsten, and confirming slight decrease of crystallinity after W addition. 3.2.2 Raman spectrometry The microstructure of the catalysts was investigated further using Raman spectroscopy. There are four primary peaks for Co0.4TiOx. As shown in Fig. 2B, the peaks at 152, 374, 639 cm−1 correspond to the three basic Raman active modes of B1 g1, Eg(1), and Eg(2) of anatase TiO2, respectively [29]. It should be noted that the peak at 690 cm−1 is attributed to the Raman activation of Co-O-Ti bond [29]. It can be clearly seen that these peaks for WaCo0.4TiOx are weaker than for Co0.4TiOx, meanwhile the Eg(1) peak gradually decreases, and other peaks gradually disappear as the W doping content increases. This phenomenon indicates that Ti-O-Ti structure is destroyed due to the formation of short-range ordered W-O-Co or W-O-Ti bonds on the surface, weakening the Ti-O-Ti and Co-O-Ti bonds and confirming the strong interaction between Co, W and Ti oxides. These results also suggest the poor crystallinity of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, which is in accord with the XRD results. 3.2.3 Results of N2 physical adsorption As displayed in Fig. 2C, type IV isotherms with H1 type hysteresis loop can be observed from the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of all samples, which also indicates that the catalyst has a mesoporous structure formed by the accumulation of nanoparticles. Compared with Co0.4TiOx (60 m2/g), the specific surface area of WaCo0.4TiOx increases significantly from 91 m2/g to 105 m2/g ( Table 1) with the addition of tungsten. This is enough to prove that the tungsten addition increases the specific surface area while exposing more active sites on the surface of catalyst, improving the SCR performance. 3.2.4 TEM images over W0.08Co0.4TiOx Due to the highest NH3-SCR activity of W0.08Co0.4TiOx, it was analyzed using TEM to examine its structure at the nanoscale scale, as shown in Fig. 3. It is clear to observe that the particles in W0.08Co0.4TiOx are agglomerated, and their size is focused in the 15–20 nm range. The high-resolution TEM image shows two lattice fringe spacings of 0.35 and 0.24 nm, which correspond to the (101) and (004) crystalline planes of anatase TiO2, respectively, and no crystalline phase of WO3, which is consistent with the XRD data. Besides, the elemental distribution mapping images in Fig. 3D-H show that W, Co, Ti, and O are equally distributed throughout the catalyst. 3.3 Surface chemical environment detection XPS analysis was used to evaluate the chemical state of the surface elements and surface composition information on the catalyst. The corresponding XPS of Co 2p, and O 1 s are displayed in Fig. 4. According to XPS test results, the proportion of W and Co on the surface is reflected in the Table 1. It can be seen that the actual proportion is less than the theoretical ratio, which indicates that there are more Co elements on the samples surface. As shown in Fig. 4A, the Co 2p curve can be fitted into two pairs of spin-orbit double peaks by utilizing a Gaussian deconvolution method, a total of four peaks. These peaks at 779.2–781.8 eV are indexed to Co3+ species, and peaks at 782.7–785.4 eV are assigned to Co2+ species [30,31]. The relative ratio of Co3+ to (Co2++Co3+) (Co3+/Co) decreases from 68.39% for the Co0.4TiOx catalyst to 34.60% for the W0.10Co0.4TiOx catalyst with increasing W content (Table 1). Moreover, it is noteworthy that the peak moves towards higher binding energy with the increase of W amount, indicating that Co electron density decreases. This also indicates that when the tungsten concentration increases in the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, the oxidation ability declines, which is compatible with the H2-TPR data. The O 1 s spectra of the WaCo0.4TiOx and Co0.4TiOx catalysts are shown in Fig. 4B. The lattice oxygen O2− (denoted as Oβ) is responsible for the sub-bands at 529.5–530.0 eV. Surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα), such as O2 2- and O- belonging to defect-oxide, and chemisorbed water or hydroxyl-like group (denoted as Oγ) are allocated to two shoulder sub-bands at 531.0–531.6 and 532.8–533.0 eV, respectively. [23,32]. When the W content increases, the binding energy of O 1 s shifts to lower value, which is caused by the strong interaction between Co and W. The ratio of Oα to O (Oα/O) was calculated based on the peak area listed in Table 1, which is 31.9–19.6% over the Co0.4TiOx and WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, respectively. Among them, the Co0.4TiOx catalyst has the highest Oα/O ratio (31.88%), demonstrating more surface adsorbed oxygen on Co0.4TiOx than WaCo0.4TiOx, which is favorable for the oxidation of NO to NO2, so producing “fast SCR” reaction on Co0.4TiOx. The W 4 f spectra of all WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts are concentrated in 34.8–35.4 and 37.0–37.6 eV (Fig. S2), corresponding to W 4 f7/2 and W 4 f5/2 of W (VI) oxidation state, respectively [26,27]. Meanwhile, the peak position of W 4 f moves to the direction of lower binding energy with increasing W amount, indicating that the electron density of W increases. It is proven that there is a considerable interaction between these components from the above XPS data of Co, W, and Ti. 3.4 Oxidation properties of the catalysts 3.4.1 Separate NO and NH3 oxidation Separate NO and NH3 oxidation reactions were carried out over the Co0.4TiOx and WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts to evaluate their oxidation ability. As illustrated in Fig. 5A, more than 90% NH3 conversion is over the Co0.4TiOx catalyst above 200 °C, which is higher than that over the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts. It is noteworthy that increasing the tungsten amount in the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts obviously brings NH3 conversion down, and the ability of these catalysts to oxidize NH3 at the same temperature is as follows: Co0.4TiOx > W0.04Co0.4TiOx > W0.06Co0.4TiOx > W0.08Co0.4TiOx > W0.10Co0.4TiOx. Fig. 5B shows the NO2 concentration during NO oxidation. The following is the order of NO2 concentrations at the same temperature: Co0.4TiOx > W0.04Co0.4TiOx > W0.06Co0.4TiOx > W0.08Co0.4TiOx > W0.10Co0.4TiOx. This is entirely the same as the NH3 conversion sequence in the separate NH3 oxidation above. The NOx-TPD data (Fig. S3) further confirm the conclusion that the adsorption capacity of nitrogen oxides gradually declines as the W doping increases, implying that adding W reduces the adsorption capacity of nitrogen oxides.The adsorbed amount of NOx on the Co0.4TiOx catalyst is the largest among all samples. The results of separate NO and NH3 oxidation suggest that the oxidation capacity of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts decreases as the increase in the tungsten amount. This is why Co0.4TiOx catalyst exhibits an excellent NH3-SCR activity at low temperature and a poor activity at high temperature. Compared with the Co0.4TiOx catalyst, the oxidation capacity of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts can be reduced by tungsten doping, enhancing the N2 selectivity by limiting NH3 over-oxidation at high temperature, resulting in a wider activity temperature window. 3.4.2 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR is an effective method for investigating oxidation ability of catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 5C, two reduction peaks at 200–380 and 400–500 °C are observed for Co0.4TiOx, which can be assigned to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co0, respectively [31,33–35]. The reduction peak shape of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts is obviously different from that of sample Co0.4TiOx, demonstrating that the introduction of tungsten can significantly affect the reducibility of the catalyst. For the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, there are four reduction peaks at 200–380, 400–530, 530–620 and ≥ 700 °C, which are labeled α, β, γ, δ. The peak α is ascribed to reduction of chemisorbed oxygen and Co3+ to Co2+, whereas the peak β is attributed to reduction of Co2+ to Co0. Peak δ in the high temperature zone where the temperature is higher than 700 °C, can be ascribed to reduction of W6+ to metallic W0 [36]. Furthermore, the intensity of the peak γ increases with the W content, showing that the peak γ is directly linked to the strong interaction between W and Co; hence, it is possible that the peak γ represents the reduction of O species in the Co-O-W bond. [37]. It can be found that, the reduction peaks shift towards high temperature with the increase of tungsten content, suggesting that the tungsten doping reduces the oxidation ability of the catalyst. The H2 consumption was calculated by fitting reduction peak area. As listed in Table 1, the H2 consumption of the peak at high temperature for WaCo0.4TiOx is obviously higher than that for Co0.4TiOx, but it does not contribute to the SCR reaction at low temperature because it belongs to the reduction of tungsten species at high temperature. Notably, the H2 consumption of peak α gradually decreases with the increase of tungsten content, which matches the oxidation capacity of the catalyst. The area ratio of the α peak to all peak (α/total) of the Co0.4TiOx and WaCo0.4TiOx (a= 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) are calculated, and the ratio follows in the order: Co0.4TiOx (29.4%) > W0.04Co0.4TiOx (26.6%) > W0.06Co0.4TiOx (17.8%) > W0.08Co0.4TiOx (14.3%) > W0.10Co0.4TiOx (12.8%), it gradually decreases with the increase of tungsten content. This reveals that the tungsten addition can weaken the oxidation ability of the catalyst, consistent with the result of separate NO and NH3 oxidation. 3.5 Acidity of the catalysts NH3-TPD test was performed over WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts to explore the effect of tungsten on catalyst acidity, and the results are shown in Fig. 6A. For all catalysts, a desorption peak between 50 and 300 °C can be clearly seen. Table 1 shows the acid quantity based on the area of the desorption peak, which is order as follows: W0.10Co0.4TiOx (101.2 μmol/g) > W0.08Co0.4TiOx (89.6 μmol/g) > W0.06Co0.4TiOx (77.4 μmol/g) ＞ W0.04Co0.4TiOx (76.1 μmol/g) ＞ Co0.4TiOx (64.4 μmol/g). Clearly, the surface acid content increases with W doping in WaCo0.4TiOx. 3.6 In-situ DRIFTS analysis 3.6.1 NH3 adsorption on WaCo0.4TiOx To investigate the acidity of catalysts and adsorption of NH3, in-situ DRIFTS was performed at 30 °C over all samples and the results are shown in Fig. 6B. The NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid (L-acid) sites are at 1151, 1197, 1224 and 1600 cm−1, whereas the NH4 + species adsorbed on Brønsted acid (B-acid) sites is responsible for the bands at 1263, 1463, 1627, and 1662 cm−1 [38,39]. The peaks at 3100–3500 cm−1 belong to the N-H stretching vibration modes of the coordinated NH3. The consumption of surface hydroxyl groups is shown by a negative peak at 3668 cm−1 (-OH) [27]. The amount of B-acid and L-acid for all catalysts was calculated by the peak area radio of every acid site in the in-situ DRIFTS and the overall acid amount obtained from the NH3-TPD results. As shown in Fig. 6C, the amounts of both B-acid and L-acid increase with the tungsten doping, moreover, the ratio of B-acid sites to L-acid sites also increases obviously, suggesting the tungsten doping is beneficial to the generation of the Brønsted acid sites on the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts. Because of the best SCR activity of W0.08Co0.4TiOx, we performed a serials of DRIFTS measurements to understand the influences of tungsten on SCR activity over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx as described below. 3.6.2 Reaction between NO+O2 and pre-adsorbed NH3 species Fig. S4 shows the DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx at 150 °C. Some peaks attributed to the NH3 adsorbed on L-acid and B-acid sites are observed, similar to those in Fig. 6B. Compared with the DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption at 30 °C (Fig. 6B), the peak of NH4 + species at 1444 cm−1 cannot be observed at 150 °C, while the peaks of coordinated NH3 are still existent [39]. Therefore, at high temperature, the NH4 + species adsorbed on the B-acid sites is not as stable as the coordinated NH3 on the L-acid sites. Fig. 7A and B show DRIFTS of the reaction between NO + O2 and the pre-adsorbed NH3 species over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx, respectively. After the saturated adsorption of NH3 on both catalysts, then N2 was used to purge. When the NO + O2 is injected, the peak intensity of the adsorbed NH3 species gradually disappears and some peaks belonged to surface nitrates are observed. The results reveal that all adsorbed NH3 can react with NO + O2 on Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx. The absorbed NH3 species on the Co0.4TiOx catalyst completely disappears in 3 min after the introduction of NO + O2, while the absorbed NH3 species on W0.08Co0.4TiOx entirely reacts for 5 min later. It indicates that the NH3 species adsorbed on Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx can react quickly with gaseous nitrogen oxides. This may be the reason why the low temperature conversion can be maintained over the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst. But the reaction rate on Co0.4TiOx is higher than that on W0.08Co0.4TiOx, which can explain the slight difference in their low-temperature activity. 3.6.3 Reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO+O2 species Fig. S5 shows that the DRIFTS of NO + O2 adsorption over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx at 150 °C, respectively. Bridging nitrate (1245, 1600, 1592, and 1228 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1536, 1579 cm−1), Co2+-NO type (1899 cm−1) surface nitroso groups, and bands are formed on the two catalysts [40–42]. Fig. 7C and D display the reaction between NH3 and the pre-adsorbed NO + O2 species over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx, respectively. For the both Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalysts, it is worth noting that after 30 min of purging N2, the peak at 1899 cm−1 disappears, demonstrating the Co2+-NO species is unstable. When NH3 is injected, the bands of nitrate species disappear rapidly, as well as the bands of adsorbed NH3 species on L and B acid sites appear over W0.08Co0.4TiOx. By contrast, for Co0.4TiOx catalyst, although the formation of NH3 species on Lewis acid and NH4 + on Brønsted acid site are also observed, the bidentate nitrate species can be maintained at 1579 cm−1. Notably, a new band occurs at 1500 cm−1, which is distinct from the described adsorption NOx and NH3 species above. The peak at 1500 cm−1 can be attributed to the vibration of NH2 species over both the Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalysts, and the NH2 species are generally considered to be active intermediates [20,43,44]. The co-adsorption of NH3 + NO + O2 on the two catalysts also confirms the existence of the NH2 species, as shown in Fig. S6. The role of NH2 species is explored in Section 3.6.4 Co-adsorption of NH3 + NO + O2 at different temperature. According to the above findings, the surface nitroso groups (Co2+-NO) is unstable and does not participate in the NH3-SCR reaction. And all nitrate species can react with NH3 over the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst, however, the bidentate nitrate species formed on the Co0.4TiOx catalyst is more stable at low temperature, so it is not easy to react with NH3. It is noteworthy that Co0.4TiOx has strong ability to adsorb nitrogen oxides to form various NOx species confirmed by the NOx-TPD results (Fig. S3), leading to its good low-temperature activity. 3.6.4 Co-adsorption of NH3 + NO + O2 at different temperature In designed to check mediates species in reaction process over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx, in-situ DRIFTS was monitored in a reaction temperature range of 20 °C to 250 °C with 1000 ppm NH3, 1000 ppm NO and 3% O2. Fig. 8 shows that many bands are observed on Co0.4TiOx at 20 °C that can be attributed to NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites (1197, 1604 cm−1), NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1432, 1668 cm−1), bridging nitrate (1238 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1579 cm−1). Notably, new bands occurred at 1324, 1500 (NH2 species), 1460 (nitrites), and 1284 cm−1 (monodentate nitrate) [45]. For both the catalysts have two things in common in this test. On the one hand is vibration peaks at 1460 and 1324 cm−1 appear at 20 °C, and their intensity decreases gradually with the increase of temperature, but the intensity of peak at 1500 cm−1 increases gradually. According to the literature [44], nitrites (1460 cm−1) and NH2 species (1324, 1500 cm−1) are considered as the active intermediates. In this study, it can be speculated that it may be NH2NO (1324 cm−1) and NH2NO2 (1500 cm−1). On the other hand, the intensity of the strong bands assigned to coordinated NH4 + on Bronsted acid sites declines, meanwhile the bands of coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites keep unchanged even at high temperature. This indicates that the adsorbed NH3 on B-acid and L-acid sites can act together in SCR reaction at low temperature, while L-acid plays a dominant role in adsorption and activation of NH3 at high temperature. Compared with Co0.4TiOx, a large number of NH4 + species adsorbed on the B acid sites can be observed at low temperature, and there is no band of bidentate nitrate at 1579 cm−1 over the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst. When temperature increases to 190 °C, the vibration peaks can still be observed on the Co0.4TiOx catalyst, but not on the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst, indicating that NH3 and nitrogen oxide species have completely reacted on the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst. It certifies the good low-temperature activity over the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst although the adsorption capacity of NOx on it is far weaker than that on the Co0.4TiOx catalyst at low temperature. Therefore, the reason for the high NO conversion over W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst at low temperature is that more acid sites, especially Brönsted acid sites, are formed after the tungsten addition, which effectively improve the adsorption and activation of ammonia species, promoting the SCR reaction. Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and Eley-Rideal (E-R) are the two most widely recognized reaction mechanisms for the NH3-SCR reaction. Combined with in-situ DRIFTS and literature reported, it can be concluded that SCR reaction on W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst occurs through L-H and E-R mechanism at low temperature, and E-R mechanism at high temperature. 3.6.5 Insight into SO2-tolerant mechanism To understand the resistance to SO2, in-situ DRIFTS of SO2 adsorption were tested over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx. As shown in Fig. 9A, some bands are clearly detected at 1625, 1361, 1295 and 1180 cm−1. The peak at 1625 cm−1 is responsible for the vibration of HSO4 − produced by the interaction of SO2 with surface hydroxyl groups. [46,47]. The asymmetric vibration of the coordinated sulfate species with covalent O = S = O peak is at 1361 cm−1. The peaks of sulfates with chelating bidentate groups are located in the 900–1300 cm−1 range. However, on the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst (Fig. 9B), there are only two weak peaks at 1614 and 1218 cm−1, which belong to the HSO4 - and bidentate sulfates groups, respectively. [48]. When the spectra of the two catalysts are compared, the peak intensity on W0.08Co0.4TiOx is far weaker than that on Co0.4TiOx, moreover, type of sulfates also is fewer on W0.08Co0.4TiOx. Furthermore, it is found that the desorption peak of sulfate above 500 °C in SO2-TPD curves moves the low temperature for W0.08Co0.4TiOx, and the peak area also becomes significantly smaller compared with Co0.4TiOx (Fig. S7). These results indicate that the tungsten addition in the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst can efficiently prevent the formation of sulfates. In addition, the DRIFTS of NO+O2 and pre-adsorbed SO2 on the Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalysts were also recorded at 150 °C to understand the influence of SO2 on NOx adsorption. It can be seen intuitively that SO2 covers the adsorption sites of NOx on the Co0.4TiOx catalyst so that NOx cannot be adsorbed (Fig. 9C). By contrast, the peaks of bridging nitrate (1245 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1536 and 1579 cm−1), and Co2+-NO type (1897 cm−1) surface nitroso groups and bridging nitrate can still be seen distinctly on the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst, suggesting the adsorption of NOx can not be influenced by SO2 (Fig. 9D). The above results show that adding tungsten to the catalyst reduces its oxidation capability and prevents SO2 from becoming SO4 2-, thus effectively preventing the reaction between SO2 and CoOx active site to generate Co2(SO4)3 and inhibiting the formation of massive sulfate. Therefore, the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst has positive SO2 resistance. 3.6.6 Effect of H2O on adsorption of NH3/NOx The DRIFTS of NO + O2 / NH3 adsorption in the presence of H2O are recorded over Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx at 150 °C to investigate the influence of water. As illustrated in Fig. 10A and B, the peak intensity of NOx species is not influenced except for surface nitroso groups (Co2+-NO) at 1899 cm−1, indicating that the adsorption of NOx on the two catalysts is unaffected by H2O. As mentioned above, Co2+-NO type (1897 cm−1) surface nitroso groups are not the species involved in the SCR reaction. However, H2O significantly weakens the adsorption of NH3 on both catalysts (Fig. 10C and D), moreover, the inhibition effect of water on ammonia adsorption is more obvious on Co0.4TiOx than W0.08Co0.4TiOx. In general, H2O has little influence on the adsorption of NOx species, however, it can significantly limit the adsorption of NH3 over the Co0.4TiOx catalyst, but has little effect on the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst. This also certify the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst has much better resistance to H2O than the Co0.4TiOx catalyst. 3.7 Kinetic study The kinetics of NH3-SCR were measured over the Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalysts. According to the literature [49–51], SCR reaction kinetics usually adopts the following empirical kinetic equation in Eq. (1). (1) rNO = k[NO]α[NH3]β[O2]γ Where rNO is the SCR reaction rate, k is the apparent rate constant, α, β, and γ represent the reaction order of NO, NH3 and O2, respectively [50,52,53]. Based on our previous work and literatures [26,42,54,55], the NH3-SCR reaction of NH3 has a strong adsorption of ammonia on the catalysts, and the reaction order (β) for NH3 is nearly zero. The presence of too much oxygen (3%) has no effect on the reaction rate. As a result, it is acceptable to include it in the reaction rate constant. In the kinetic test, only the reaction order of NO is discussed on Co0.4TiOx and W0.08Co0.4TiOx at different temperature shown in the Fig. 11. The measurements were performed by changing the NO inlet concentration in the range of 500–1000 ppm, keeping another reactant NH3 at 500 ppm, and O2 being 3% to obtain NO conversion. As presented in Fig. 11A, the reaction order α of NO is between 0.69 and 0.65 for Co0.4TiOx, which is less than the first order reaction [49,50]. It is worth noting that the difference in the reaction order of NO is very small and close to 0.7 at different temperature, implying that NO as an adsorbed state may be a role in the low temperature SCR process, primarily via the L-H mechanism over Co0.4TiOx. For W0.08Co0.4TiOx, the reaction order of NO (α) is between 1.18 and 0.88, close to first order [51,56], suggesting that NO participates in the SCR reaction in the form of gas or weak adsorption confirmed by the DRIFTS of the NOx adsorption (Fig. S4). Thus, we think the SCR reaction over W0.08Co0.4TiOx mainly follows the E-R pathway. 3.8 Influence of W doping on NH3-SCR activity Overall, by introducing W into the Co0.4TiOx mixed oxides catalyst, we have synthesized the WaCo0.4TiOx (a = 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) mixed oxides catalysts that show great NH3-SCR performance. Compared with the Co0.4TiOx catalyst, the high-temperature catalytic activity, SO2 durability, and N2 selectivity all improve dramatically when the doping amount of W is steadily increased. Among these samples, W0.08Co0.4TiOx has the widest temperature range under above 90% NO conversion, the best N2 selectivity, and better resistance against SO2 and/or H2O. According to various characterization results, we think that the tungsten doping can adjust surface species compositions physical properties, surface acidity, and redox ability of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, thereby enhancing their NH3-SCR performance. Compared with the Co0.4TiOx, the surface area of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts is enhanced, indicating that W doping has a significant impact on the catalyst structure (Table 1). Only peaks belonging to the anatase structure of TiO2 are detected in the XRD patterns of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, rather than diffraction peaks corresponding to any cobalt and tungsten crystallite phases, implying that the Co and W species form the amorphous structure or finely disperse on the sample surface. (Fig. 2). Compared with the H2-TPR results (Fig. 5) of WaCo0.4TiOx and Co0.4TiOx, the oxidation capacity of the WaCo0.4TiOx samples after W doping is significantly affected. The more W amount in WaCo0.4TiOx it is, the lesser oxidation capacity it has, following the order: Co0.4TiOx > W0.04Co0.4TiOx > W0.06Co0.4TiOx > W0.08Co0.4TiOx > W0.10Co0.4TiOx. In addition, separate NH3 and NO oxidation experiments came to the same outcome, confirming that increasing W content limits oxidation. In general, the decrease of oxidation capacity can prevent over-oxidation of NH3, leading to good NO conversion and high N2 selectivity at high temperature. This can be explained that good NH3-SCR de-NOx performance of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts with wide activity temperature window. Furthermore, according to the XPS data (Fig. 4), when W doping for the WaCo0.4TiOx samples, the amount of the surface oxygen species and Co3+ decreases, confirming that the W introduction has a significant negative influence on the oxidation capacity of the WaCo0.4TiOx samples. It is well known that the improved NO oxidation to NO2 to perform the "fast SCR" (NO2 + 2NH3 + NO→ 2 N2 + 3 H2O) reaction is one of the crucial factors for improving low-temperature activity. However, at low temperature, the activity of the WaCo0.4TiOx and Co0.4TiOx catalysts is nearly identical, although the oxidation capacity of WaCo0.4TiOx is lower than that of Co0.4TiOx. Therefore, we believe that oxidation capacity of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts is not the primary consideration in controlling the activity of NH3-SCR at low temperature. As well known, acidity has a significant impact on NH3-SCR reaction, with NH3 adsorption and activation being a critical step. (Fig. 6A) Based on the NH3-TPD results, the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts have more acid amount and acid sites than the Co0.4TiOx catalysts, indicating that the W addition improves the acidity of the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts. Furthermore, the DRIFTS results demonstrate that adding W increases not only the adsorption of NH3 species (Fig. 6B), but also the percentage of B-acid sites, over the WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts, especially W0.08Co0.4TiOx, which is helpful for low temperature SCR activity. Although W0.10Co0.4TiOx catalyst has the largest acid amount, its low-temperature SCR activity is not as good as other samples due to the aggregation of WO3 on the catalyst to cover the Co active sites, greatly weakening the oxidation capacity of the catalyst. In short, although the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst shows much lower oxidation ability than the Co0.4TiOx catalyst, the low-temperature activity does not decrease obviously, which can be put down to the development of more acidic sites, especial B acid sites, after appropriate W addition, enhancing the adsorption and activation of NH3 species on W0.08Co0.4TiOx. Thus, we suggest that the synergistic effect between oxidation ability and acidity can bring about the much better NH3-SCR activity at low temperature and higher N2 selectivity at high temperature over W0.08Co0.4TiOx. 4 Conclusions The W modified CoTiOx catalysts (WaCo0.4TiOx) were prepared for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NOx. The optimal W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst can obtain above 90% NOx conversion at 190–430 °C and near 100% N2 selectivity with good resistance to H2O/SO2. The interaction of Co and W increases the specific surface area and metal oxide dispersion, and enhances the surface activity of WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts. The introduction of W reduces the oxidation capacity of the catalyst, but enhances the acidic sites, especially the B acid content which is more conducive to the adsorption and activation of NH3 at low temperature, consequently leading to good low temperature activity. Therefore, both low and high temperature performance and N2 selectivity of the catalyst are significantly improved after W introduction in WaCo0.4TiOx. In-situ DRIFTS analysis suggest that the addition of W can decrease the influence of SO2 and H2O on SCR activity of the catalyst, thus improving the resistance of the catalyst to sulfur and water. In the meanwhile, the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst shows obvious decrease in NOx adsorption ability compared with the Co0.4TiOx catalyst. As a result, the E-R mechanism mainly dominates the SCR reaction at both low and high temperature over the W0.08Co0.4TiOx catalyst, although the L-H processes can occur in the SCR reaction over the catalyst. In general, we believe that the decreased oxidizability can be compensated for by increasing the surface B-acid sites, thus improving the low-temperature SCR activity and high-temperature nitrogen selectivity. coredata.dc:description: A serial of WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts (a = 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10) was synthesized by sol-gel method, which exhibited high NH3-SCR denitrification performance in a wide activity temperature window. W0.08Co0.4TiOx achieve best SCR activity (over 90% NO conversion) at 190–430 °C and good resistance to H2O/SO2. Various characterizations were used to investigate the influence of W doping on physicochemical property of these catalysts. Especially, in-situ DRIFTS were used to evaluate the type of acid sites, NOx adsorption, the reactivity of surface adsorption species, and the influences of H2O/SO2 on adsorption of NOx and NH3. The doping of W enhanced the acidity and weakened the oxidation capacity of WaCo0.4TiOx, but higher surface acidity, especial more Brønsted acid sites, can compensate for the effect of the decrease in the oxidation capacity on low-temperature activity. The optimal activity over W0.08Co0.4TiOx can be derived from the synergistic effect of surface acidity and oxidation performance.
coredata.dc:title: Improving NH3-SCR denitrification performance over WaCo0.4TiOx catalysts: Effect of surface acidity due to W addition on low-temperature and high-temperature activity
